title: UK police arrest Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor
subhead: The younger brother of Britain's King Charles has been arrested on Thursday on suspicion of misconduct during his time as a trade envoy. New revelations appeared to show Andrew sent convicted US sex offender Jeffrey Epstein potentially confidential documents.

title: Epstein files hand French prosecutors trove of new leads
The foretold crash of the French-German fighter jet
Gaza's local authorities massively underreported deaths, says international research team
subhead: The first independent field study on Gaza to not involve local authorities, published in The Lancet Global Health on Wednesday, concludes that the number of violent deaths linked to the conflict has been underreported by about 35%.

title: Nestlé exits ice cream market and partially withdraws from bottled water
subhead: Rocked by a scandal involving potentially contaminated baby formula, Nestlé stated that its 'recall is completed' and that 'production has resumed at all infant formula factories, using alternative ingredient suppliers.'

title: In 'Coutures,' Alice Winocour explores the fashion world amid a backdrop of hospital melodrama
subhead: The director sets star actress Angelina Jolie in the world behind the scenes of fashion week, switching a satire of the fashion industry for a more intimate story.

title: Xavier Dolan, filmmaker: "Where does the idea that artists should 'stay out of politics' come from?"
subhead: A controversy is stirring at this year's Berlinale. At their opening press conference, the jury members declined to comment on the situation in Palestine, with their president, Wim Wenders, arguing that cinema should 'stay out of politics.' Canadian director Xavier Dolan responds to him in an op-ed for Le Monde.

title: Louvre robbery reveals 'systemic failures,' inquiry finds
France to arm railway and metro police with stun guns
Christine Lagarde may leave European Central Bank before end of term
France's image deteriorates in the eyes of American investors
South Korean ex-president Yoon Suk Yeol sentenced to life in prison for insurrection
Israel conducting 'gradual de facto annexation' of West Bank, UN official says
How Ukraine defends its railway infrastructure
Europe is divided over Trump's Board of Peace
Mélenchon's strategy of conflict under fire after far-right activist's killing
Hacker accessed data from 1.2 million bank accounts, French Economy Ministry says
Eleven arrested in probe over far-right activist's death, with far-left group under scrutiny
Leila Shahid, former Palestinian diplomat, has died
Anthropic, the AI start-up that dares to defy Donald Trump
subhead: Dario Amodei, the CEO of the artificial intelligence company, acknowledged disagreements with the White House over the regulation and military use of his technology. This is a rare stance in the US, where the tech industry has generally pledged allegiance to the president.

title: Kyiv's fourth winter at war has spared no one
subhead: In the freezing Ukrainian capital, residents are regularly without heat and electricity. People get by through resourcefulness and solidarity, living with a sense of inevitability.

title: Teens on France's social media ban for under-15s: 'We're going back to the Stone Age'
subhead: The measure to ban social media for those under age 15 would affect mostly middle schoolers. About a dozen of them shared their concerns with Le Monde about a law set to upend their online lives.

title: 'The spectacle of European disunity in the face of pressure from both the United States and China is infuriating'
Rejecting political violence
Paul Magnette, political scientist: 'If Trump's camp felt superior, why try and divide Europe?'
